title: Keir Starmer issued brutal 'red tape' warning over thousands of Brits in crisis
description: A charity has warned that many working Britons are struggling to feed themselves and their families, and are unable to know if they are entitled to help.
content:
A food club chain founder said Labour must end UK food poverty, as his volunteers treat 4,500 more families to hot meals over the summer holiday. Father-of-two Mark Game, 56, set up 'The Bread and Butter Thing' in Manchester with partner Jane from the back of a van in 2016, to help those battling on the breadline. Now the charity, which charges just £8.50 for three big bags of fruit and veg, cupboard staples and chilled goods to needy members, operates 145 hubs from Northumberland to Maidstone, helping 100,000 people. Their recent study found that after paying for rent and energy bills, almost 70% of households have less than £50 per person each month to cover food, clothing, toiletries, transport and other essentials.

This summer, thanks to Sainsbury’s Nourish the Nation campaign and Comic Relief, they are creating 4,549 activity places for kids who don’t meet the Department for Education’s Holiday Activities and Food Programme (HAF) criteria. But founder Mark told the Daily Express that more struggling Britons are being denied access to vital benefits and support by endless government red tape. He told us: "We have to recognise just how difficult it is for everyday people just to be able to get by. "People are stopping going on holidays, people are seeing takeaways as a luxury, and these are families that are just working every day and in reasonable jobs. These are not people who are destitute. "A recent study said annually there's about £22 billion worth of unclaimed benefits. And this is because of all the barriers that are in place. The government doesn't spend time trying to tell people what's available." The Bread and Butter Thing was founded by Mark and his partner in 2016 with a simple but powerful mission: to make life easier for people struggling to feed themselves or their families. It describes its food clubs as "the secret weapon in the fight against food insecurity, solving two problems in one go – diverting surplus food and filling empty fridges." Mark said: "Each food club that we run can serve about 80 families a week. We offer a bag of cupboard goods, a bag of fruit and veg and a bag of chilled goods. And it's a push model, a bit like a veg box scheme. "You get what you're given because it's surplus on the day, and it's whatever we've got. But it's nutritious. "We see a lot of people who have disabilities, on benefits, low income from work or retired with no pension. They're not destitute, but they're stretched, they're strained, they're really struggling. "One accident or one need of a school uniform can tip them over the edge. Over half of our members are in work. We'll see nurses, teaching assistants, carers, cleaners, builders and network IT consultants. "One member I can think of is a data analyst for the Ministry of Justice. I say 'a data analyst, that's a decent wage. Why are you coming?' He said 'when I came out of my fixed term on my mortgage, my mortgage quadrupled!'"

Earlier this year, the charity released their 'Slice of Life' report, which urged Labour to simplify systems and introduce auto-enrolment for people who qualify for low-income benefits - using "existing data to reduce bureaucracy and ensure people receive the help they qualify for". Policy in Practice's "Missing Out 2024" study revealed £22.7 billion of income-related benefits and social tariffs go unclaimed in the UK annually - a significant increase from previous estimates. Mark explained: "If you're a working family and you don't engage with the job centre, then where do you go to understand what help is available for you? "If people are actually working, why should we make it difficult for them to actually access this additional support that's out there for them? "So it's really easy to fix - you auto-enrol people. The government knows exactly who's on what pay rate and who should be able to actually access these benefits. "I'll give you an example. The NHS has something called the Low Income Scheme for dentistry and optometry, but it's a 20-page application form! It's just so difficult. "The Government doesn't spend time trying to tell people what benefits are available. There's no central resource to be able to actually find this stuff. "If you lose a job tomorrow, you've got a hell of a lot of Googling and phone calls to make to find out what's actually out there for you." It's claimed that 45% of working households do not know what support they’re entitled to, and almost a quarter say they don’t know whether they’re receiving their full entitlements. In addition to auto-enrolling people on benefits and increasing funding of holiday clubs, Mark said the government could also consider widening eligibility for children to have free school meals and, crucially, tackling food inflation costs. He added: "Food is getting more and more expensive, but because it's been happening for so long, it's almost normalised." In June, The Bread and Butter Thing was awarded £1,264,774 in funding from the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) as part of its Tackling Food Surplus at the Farm Gate programme. Every year, an estimated 330,000 tonnes of edible food are either wasted or repurposed as animal feed before leaving farm gates.

And now that the summer holidays are in full swing, The Bread and Butter Thing has been able to help more families have a break with its Holiday Activities and Food (HAF) Around the Hub programme. Funded through Sainsbury’s and Comic Relief, the initiative includes creative activities, day trips, hot meals, and a free food shop at The Bread and Butter Thing. The programme will support 33 communities and create 4,549 places for children who don’t meet the Department for Education’s HAF criteria. In addition to the HAF activity over the six-week summer period, The Bread and Butter Thing will distribute an estimated 600,000 food bag sets to its members with children at home. Vic Harper, CEO of The Bread and Butter Thing says: "We know that money gets tighter over the school holidays, when support drops away, but pressures only increase. "We hear from our communities that programmes like HAF Around the Hub are allowing for valuable memories to be made with their children, despite the current financial challenges. "Holiday provision is vital, but so is consistency; that’s why we keep all our food clubs running throughout summer. Providing access to affordable, nutritious food is an everyday thing, not just a term thing." Samir Patel, CEO of Comic Relief said: "Food poverty is a reality facing millions of people across the UK this summer and for so many families who are already on the brink financially, the need to provide extra food for their children during the holidays only adds to worries and concerns that are being felt every day. "We’re proud to be supporting The Bread and Butter Thing and their vitally important work that is providing access to essentials, nutritious food, and creative activities that are helping to ease the burden on families during the holidays." The Government told us a total of £1 billion to reform crisis support has been announced in the Spending Review with their Child Poverty Taskforce building an ambitious strategy to reduce child poverty as part of the Plan for Change. They added: "This Government is determined to change people’s lives for the better, helping them out of poverty and tackling the unacceptable rise in food bank dependence in recent years. "As part of our Plan for Change, we are offering free school meals to every single child from a household that claims Universal Credit, lifting 100,000 children out of poverty, as well as making changes to Universal Credit to give a £420 boost to over one million households." "We are also reforming the social security system so it genuinely supports those who can work into employment and ensures the safety net will always be there for the most vulnerable." * To donate and support The Bread and Butter Thing visit https://www.breadandbutterthing.org/
summary: Mark Game, founder of 'The Bread and Butter Thing' food club chain in Manchester, has called for the Labour Party to tackle UK food poverty, stating that it is making it harder for everyday people to access vital benefits and support. The charity, which charges just £8.50 per bag of fruit and veg, provides hot meals to 4,500 more families during summer holidays for those struggling to feed themselves or their families. A study found that after paying for rent and energy bills, almost 70% of households have less than £50 per person each month. Founder Mark Game argues that the government is failing to inform people of what benefits are available and how to access these benefits. He also highlighted the issue of unclaimed benefits, which annually amounts to £22 billion in the UK to go unclaimed. Policy in Practice's "Missing Out 2024" study revealed that £22.7 billion of income-related benefits and social tariffs are unclaimed annually, a significant increase from previous estimates. The report urges Labour to simplify systems and introduce auto-enrolment for people who qualify for low-income benefits.
shortSummary: The Bread and Butter Thing founder urges Labour to simplify benefits systems and introduce auto-enrolment to end UK food poverty, highlighting widespread government bureaucracy and unclaimed benefits.

A Slice of Life
If help exists but no one knows about it... is it really help?
Millions of working families are missing out on vital support because they don’t even know it exists. Or worse, they know it exists but can’t access it due to overcomplicated paperwork. And that’s why we're making waves on the Thames. To launch our latest piece of research, the Slice of Life report, right in the heart of Westminster to highlight a broken system that’s failing working people who are struggling to keep their heads above water.
We know that there is no such thing as a ‘typical’ Bread and Butter member. And as part of our latest survey, we wanted to share what life really looks like for our membership. Our members are from diverse backgrounds and household types, yet they all have one thing in common: each week, they maximise their income, connect with their community and improve their diets simply by coming to our food clubs.
This year’s survey shows that while food banks are crucial in a crisis, long-term solutions like our food clubs are key for lasting food security. Ultimately, our findings show how financial instability, food insecurity, and support systems are all interconnected and stress the importance of community.
Download links
What’s needed?
A national food security strategy that reduces need for crisis support:
The government’s upcoming food strategy must prioritise prevention, ensuring families are supported before falling into crisis. This should include expanding affordable food access, school meal programmes, and affordable nutritional initiatives. Food insecurity must be treated as a systemic issue connected to low wages, housing, and social support; not just a series of isolated crises.
Too many working families miss out on the support they are entitled to due to complex application processes. The government should simplify systems and introduce auto-enrolment where possible, using existing data to reduce bureaucracy and ensure people receive the help they qualify for.
Simplifying and streamlining access to government support:
Many working households fall through the cracks—earning too much for help but too little to cover essential costs. Life is not affordable. Expanding eligibility criteria for support schemes would provide critical relief to families struggling with the cost of living.
Raising eligibility thresholds for financial support:
Government must ensure that affordability—for food, housing, and essentials—is a core principle across all policy making. Strategies should reduce reliance on emergency support and focus on sustainable solutions that lift communities out of persistent hardship.
Embed long-term affordability in future policy design:
Why we're taking our message to Westminster: Life isn't affordable and people cannot keep their heads above water
At The Bread and Butter Thing, we’re known for our food clubs, not for political stunts. But sometimes, when the reality on the ground is being ignored in Westminster, we must speak out, and raise our voices.
That’s why we’re heading to Parliament. Not with placards and protest chants, but with a powerful visual of people barely keeping their heads above water. Because that's what life feels like for millions across the UK right now.
Read more about it right here
Help is out there and we’re on a mission to make it easier to access
As a start, we’ve pulled together an easy-to-use snapshot of all the Government and charity support that exists out there, from energy advice to NHS low-income support and more. Take a closer look right here…
Listen to our Slice of Life podcast special
Meet Carer James, a support worker and devoted young dad doing everything he can to make sure his little boy is well fed. Even with two incomes and careful budgeting, James and his partner still find themselves struggling to cover the basics.

argos_summary: Mark Game, founder of 'The Bread and Butter Thing', emphasizes the urgent need for the UK government to address food poverty as his charity provides affordable meals to struggling families. Operating 145 hubs, the organization serves over 100,000 people, revealing that many working families are unaware of the benefits they qualify for due to bureaucratic hurdles. Game advocates for simplified access to support and auto-enrollment in benefits to alleviate the financial strain on households, particularly during the summer when expenses increase.
